Summary Maria is the Head of Talent, Culture & Advocacy for Marketing and Communications at IBM. She joins the Marketing & Communications leadership team to accelerate and scale the redesign of the function by creating programs and rituals that promote and reinforce a unique culture. 
 
Previously, as the Head of Global Recruiting & External Relations for IBM Design, Maria was responsible for building high-performing product design teams. Maria joined IBM Design at its inception and took on the mission of closing a massive talent gap of designers within our Cloud, Analytics, Social, Security, & Watson business units. She led the talent team for 2.5 years which successfully sourced, evaluated, hired, and on-boarded 450+ designers into IBM Studios worldwide in a whole new way. By sharing IBM's story at events, developing partnerships with top design universities & communities, implementing a high-touch recruiting program, and overhauling the entire experience to be engaging & highly responsive within a competitive market – her team attracted thousands of candidates and achieved an 83% offer acceptance rate. She was also involved with the deployment strategy of designers and helped create programs dedicated to educating + activating IBMers in IBM Design Thinking, in addition to limiting attrition & building out IBM's global product design studios.  
 
Before IBM Design, Maria led various product launch activities, set best practices to help drive millions of dollars in software + services sales and maintained relationships with many Fortune 500 clients as a Product Marketing Manager for IBM's Smarter Process portfolio. She joined IBM with the 2010 acquisition of Lombardi Software where she was integral to the integration process of Lombardi as well as go-to-market strategy of industry-leading BPM technology. Maria holds a bachelor's of science degree in Industrial & Operations Engineering from the University of Michigan. She is from New York and currently calls Austin, Texas home. Summary Malcolm Gladwell would say that I invested my most recent 10,000 hours for expertise in “IBM.” While this doesn’t always translate to the outside world, it essentially means that I’ve been asked to take on such a wide variety of challenges in my eight years here that I know just enough about most things to be dangerous. But whether it was cities, semiconductors, or CFOs, I’ve always looked at each new challenge through the lens of an entrepreneur. I put my business development and management consulting skills to work, adding the creativity and imagination to envision the possible, and then the leadership to get everyone together to make something from nothing. The result is first-of-a-kind programs, new businesses, licensing revenue, effective strategies, new insights from analytics, cultural change, publications, and even a patent. 
 
Who is Justin Cook? Some call me a “want-to-be academic,” a claim largely supported by the evidence. I enjoy things like analytics competitions and I liked business school so much I essentially went twice. The first time was for a B.S. at Wharton and then I went back again many years later for an MBA at MIT Sloan. I’ve given talks at conferences and to graduate students in auditoriums at USC, Carnegie Mellon, and The Tokyo Institute of Technology. However I didn’t “want-to-be” an academic enough as I turned down PhD program acceptances at Yale and Columbia in favor of working in the exciting world known as the technology industry.
